data.meta_description: 'God's Not Dead' stunned Hollywood and helped usher in a new era of faith and family-friendly entertainment when the movie brought in more than $60 million after its 2014 release.

With just a $1.5 million budget, the movieâ€™s more than $60 million profit sent a clear message to Tinseltown that there was an underserved Christian audience hungry for uplifting and positive messages.

A decade later, producers are gearing up for the fifth installment of the film franchise.

â€œGodâ€™s Not Dead: In God We Trust,â€ which hits theaters nationwide Sept. 12, â€œexplores the intersection of faith, politics, and our civic duty.â€

Coming at a time of cultural chaos â€” a time when people fear cancellation and other social ills â€” â€œGodâ€™s Not Dead: In God We Trustâ€ tackles the importance of standing up for oneâ€™s beliefs and taking action to have a positive impact.

â€œSet in a time of political and spiritual upheaval, â€˜Godâ€™s Not Dead: In God We Trust followsâ€™ Reverend David Hill as he runs for Congress following the sudden death of an incumbent,â€ a synopsis reads. â€œFacing a powerful adversary intent on removing religion from governance, the film emphasizes the significance of religious values in shaping policy and governance.â€

The movie stars David A.R. White, Isaiah Washington, Dean Cain, Scott Baio, and many others. White reprises his role as Reverend David Hill, the beloved preacher facing yet another moral â€” and this time, legislative â€” battle.

â€œNow more than ever, Christians must realize that we are being called to deliver hope to a country thatâ€™s feeling hopeless,â€ Hill proclaims from the pulpit in the movieâ€™s trailer. â€œFaith begins where your comfort zone ends. We need to step out into that faith.â€

It seems Hill will be the one whose faith is once again put to the test in this new â€œGodâ€™s Not Deadâ€ adventure. For more on the film, stay tuned to the movieâ€™s official website.
